inputs.text: Could you please implement authentication for the API?

elements.text: Could you please implement authentication for the API?
elements.explanation: Phrased as a question with modal 'could' and politeness marker 'please', but functions as a request/command for action rather than inquiry about ability.
elements.implied_meaning: I want you to implement authentication for the API

elements.text: Could you please implement authentication for the API?
elements.explanation: Presupposes that: (1) authentication is not currently implemented, (2) recipient has ability to implement it, (3) authentication is needed/valuable.
elements.implied_meaning: Authentication does not exist yet and needs to be added

metadata.notes: Classic indirect speech act - polite request disguised as ability question

inputs.text: It would be great if we had real-time notifications.

elements.text: It would be great if we had real-time notifications.
elements.explanation: Conditional 'would be great' expresses desire/wish, but pragmatically functions as a feature request. Speaker is not merely expressing opinion but requesting implementation.

elements.text: It would be great if we had real-time notifications.
elements.explanation: Presupposes real-time notifications don't currently exist ('if we had' implies we don't have them now).
elements.implied_meaning: Real-time notifications are not currently implemented

metadata.notes: Tests Wish speech act and presupposition of absence

inputs.text: Have you finished the migration? The deadline was yesterday.

elements.explanation: Direct question seeking information about completion status. Genuine inquiry, not disguised request.
States fact about deadline, but implicates urgency, possible criticism for lateness, and expectation that work should be complete. Creates pressure without explicit criticism.
elements.implied_meaning: The migration should be done by now; you may be late

elements.explanation: Presupposes: (1) there is a migration task, (2) recipient is responsible for it, (3) it was supposed to be finished.
elements.implied_meaning: You are responsible for completing the migration

metadata.notes: Tests Implicature (implied criticism) and multiple presuppositions

inputs.text: I promise to have the feature deployed by Friday.

elements.text: I promise to have the feature deployed by Friday.
elements.explanation: Explicit performative verb 'promise' commits speaker to future action. Creates obligation and expectation of follow-through.
elements.implied_meaning: You can count on this being done by Friday; I am committed

elements.text: I promise to have the feature deployed by Friday.
elements.explanation: Presupposes: (1) there is a specific feature to deploy, (2) speaker has control over deployment, (3) Friday is the target date, (4) it's not deployed yet.
elements.implied_meaning: The feature exists but is not yet deployed

metadata.notes: Clear Promise speech act with explicit performative verb

inputs.text: The code is clean and well-structured. No issues found during review.

elements.text: The code is clean and well-structured.
elements.explanation: Statement of fact (or opinion presented as fact) about code quality. Direct assertion, no hidden meaning.
Factual statement about review outcome. Reinforces positive assessment from first sentence.

elements.text: The code is clean and well-structured. No issues found during review.
elements.explanation: Presupposes a code review was conducted. 'During review' implies review happened.
elements.implied_meaning: A code review process was completed

metadata.notes: Straightforward assertions with minimal pragmatic complexity

inputs.text: We should probably add logging. It might help with debugging.

elements.explanation: Modal 'should' with hedge 'probably' softens the directive, but pragmatically functions as a recommendation/request for action. Not merely stating opinion.
elements.implied_meaning: Please add logging to the system

elements.explanation: Provides justification for adding logging. 'Might help' is hedged, but implicates speaker believes logging would be beneficial, not just a remote possibility.
elements.implied_meaning: Logging will likely be useful for debugging

elements.explanation: Presupposes logging is not currently implemented ('add' implies it doesn't exist).
elements.implied_meaning: Logging is not currently in place

metadata.notes: Tests hedged request with justification and implicature

inputs.text: Fix this bug immediately! The production system is down and customers are complaining.

elements.explanation: Imperative mood with intensifier 'immediately' and exclamation mark. Direct command with urgency.
elements.implied_meaning: This is critical and must be done now

elements.text: The production system is down and customers are complaining.
elements.explanation: Provides justification for urgency. Implicates: (1) situation is serious, (2) business impact is significant, (3) delay is not acceptable, (4) recipient should prioritize this above other work.
elements.implied_meaning: This is a critical issue affecting revenue and reputation; drop everything else

elements.explanation: Presupposes: (1) there is a specific bug, (2) recipient knows about it ('this bug'), (3) recipient has ability to fix it, (4) bug is causing the outage.
elements.implied_meaning: You know about this bug and are capable of fixing it

metadata.notes: Tests urgent Command with high-stakes justification
